description: Provides information about the internal battery of a laptop. Note: On Windows, columns with Ah or mAh units assume that the battery is 12V.

columns.description: One of the following: "AC Power" indicates the battery is connected to an external power source, "Battery Power" indicates that the battery is drawing internal power, "Off Line" indicates the battery is off-line or no longer connected

columns.description: 1 if the battery is currently being charged by a power source. 0 otherwise

columns.name: charged
columns.description: 1 if the battery is currently completely charged. 0 otherwise

columns.name: designed_capacity
columns.description: The battery's designed capacity in mAh

columns.name: max_capacity
columns.description: The battery's actual capacity when it is fully charged in mAh

columns.name: current_capacity
columns.description: The battery's current capacity (level of charge) in mAh

columns.name: percent_remaining
columns.description: The percentage of battery remaining before it is drained

columns.name: amperage
columns.description: The current amperage in/out of the battery in mA (positive means charging, negative means discharging)

columns.name: voltage
columns.description: The battery's current voltage in mV

columns.name: minutes_until_empty
columns.description: The number of minutes until the battery is fully depleted. This value is -1 if this time is still being calculated

columns.name: minutes_to_full_charge
columns.description: The number of minutes until the battery is fully charged. This value is -1 if this time is still being calculated. On Windows this is calculated from the charge rate and capacity and may not agree with the number reported in "Power & Battery"

columns.name: chemistry
columns.description: The battery chemistry type (eg. LiP). Some possible values are documented in https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/power/battery-information-str.

columns.name: health
columns.description: One of the following: "Good" describes a well-performing battery, "Fair" describes a functional battery with limited capacity, or "Poor" describes a battery that's not capable of providing power

columns.name: condition
columns.description: One of the following: "Normal" indicates the condition of the battery is within normal tolerances, "Service Needed" indicates that the battery should be checked out by a licensed Mac repair service, "Permanent Failure" indicates the battery needs replacement

columns.name: manufacture_date
columns.description: The date the battery was manufactured UNIX Epoch

name: unified_log
description: Queries the OSLog framework for entries in the system log. The maximum number of rows returned is limited for performance issues. Use timestamp > or >= constraints to optimize query performance. This table introduces a new idiom for extracting sequential data in batches using multiple queries, ordered by timestamp. To trigger it, the user should include the condition "timestamp > -1", and the table will handle pagination. Note that the saved pagination counter is incremented globally across all queries and table invocations within a query. To avoid multiple table invocations within a query, use only AND and = constraints in WHERE clause.

columns.name: build_number

description: Windows Event logs.

columns.description: ICMP types and codes for the rule

columns.description: 1 if the rule profile type is public

columns.name: service_name

columns.name: state
columns.description: Installation state value. 1 == Enabled, 2 == Disabled, 3 == Absent

name: windows_search
description: Run searches against the Windows system index database using Advanced Query Syntax. See https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/search/-search-3x-advancedquerysyntax for details.

columns.name: path
columns.description: The full path of the item.

columns.name: date_created
columns.description: The unix timestamp of when the item was created.

columns.name: date_modified
columns.description: The unix timestamp of when the item was last modified

columns.name: max_results
columns.description: Maximum number of results returned by windows api, set to -1 for unlimited

columns.name: additional_properties
columns.description: Comma separated list of columns to include in properties JSON

name: windows_security_center
description: The health status of Window Security features. Health values can be "Good", "Poor". "Snoozed", "Not Monitored", and "Error".

columns.description: The health of the monitored Firewall (see windows_security_products)

columns.name: autoupdate
columns.description: The health of the Windows Autoupdate feature

columns.name: internet_settings
columns.description: The health of the Internet Settings

columns.name: windows_security_center_service
columns.description: The health of the Windows Security Center Service

columns.name: user_account_control
columns.description: The health of the User Account Control (UAC) capability in Windows

name: windows_security_products
description: Enumeration of registered Windows security products. Note: Not compatible with Windows Server.

columns.name: signatures_up_to_date
columns.description: 1 if product signatures are up to date, else 0

name: windows_update_history
description: Provides the history of the windows update events.

columns.description: Identifier of the client application that processed an update

columns.name: date
columns.description: Date and the time an update was applied

columns.name: hresult

columns.name: result_code
columns.description: Result of an operation on an update

columns.name: server_selection
columns.description: Value that indicates which server provided an update

columns.description: Service identifier of an update service that is not a Windows update

name: wmi_bios_info
description: Lists important information from the system bios.

name: wmi_cli_event_consumers
description: WMI CommandLineEventConsumer, which can be used for persistence on Windows. See https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-15/materials/us-15-Graeber-Abusing-Windows-Management-Instrumentation-WMI-To-Build-A-Persistent%20Asynchronous-And-Fileless-Backdoor-wp.pdf for more details.

columns.name: command_line_template
columns.description: Standard string template that specifies the process to be started. This property can be NULL, and the ExecutablePath property is used as the command line.

columns.name: executable_path
columns.description: Module to execute. The string can specify the full path and file name of the module to execute, or it can specify a partial name. If a partial name is specified, the current drive and current directory are assumed.

columns.name: relative_path
columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.

name: wmi_event_filters
description: Lists WMI event filters.

columns.name: name
columns.description: Unique identifier of an event filter.

columns.name: query
columns.description: Windows Management Instrumentation Query Language (WQL) event query that specifies the set of events for consumer notification, and the specific conditions for notification.

columns.name: query_language
columns.description: Query language that the query is written in.

columns.name: relative_path
columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.

name: wmi_filter_consumer_binding
description: Lists the relationship between event consumers and filters.

columns.name: consumer
columns.description: Reference to an instance of __EventConsumer that represents the object path to a logical consumer, the recipient of an event.

columns.name: filter
columns.description: Reference to an instance of __EventFilter that represents the object path to an event filter which is a query that specifies the type of event to be received.

columns.name: relative_path
columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.

name: wmi_script_event_consumers
description: WMI ActiveScriptEventConsumer, which can be used for persistence on Windows. See https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-15/materials/us-15-Graeber-Abusing-Windows-Management-Instrumentation-WMI-To-Build-A-Persistent%20Asynchronous-And-Fileless-Backdoor-wp.pdf for more details.

columns.name: name
columns.description: Unique identifier for the event consumer.

columns.name: scripting_engine
columns.description: Name of the scripting engine to use, for example, 'VBScript'. This property cannot be NULL.

columns.name: script_file_name
columns.description: Name of the file from which the script text is read, intended as an alternative to specifying the text of the script in the ScriptText property.

columns.name: script_text
columns.description: Text of the script that is expressed in a language known to the scripting engine. This property must be NULL if the ScriptFileName property is not NULL.

columns.name: relative_path
columns.description: Relative path to the class or instance.
